reviewText: With your choice of 3 classes(each with different trainable skill sets) you'll embark on a fairly uneventful dungeon crawler through three forgettable locales each with their own distinct mobs. While the classes and builds make for a bit of intrigue you'll quickly be mired in repetition as you clear room after room without much to distinguish each one from the last. In typical crawler fashion the game is broken into three acts each capped by an uninspiring boss encounter. The game also features an incredibly frustrating lack of responsiveness from the controls. Attempts to pivot and free fire are often ignored as you find yourself running directly into damage(and often death) instead. While it had the potential to be a good title there just isn't enough there to warrant the time commitment and achievement collectors will also be disappointed at the absence of any. Unless you are a die hard fan of the genre or have a fetish for poor controls I'd suggest spending your time elsewhere.

reviewText:
Faulty's scorecard :-

1) Essential purchase
2) Recommended purchase
3) Recommended purchase during a sale4) Not recommended unless heavily discounted
5) Not even recommended for Steam game collectors

Whilst technically there is nothing wrong with Clockstone software latest game, it's missing the charm that accompanied its previous title, Avencast. Greed: Black Border is about as mechanical as games can get. The pieces all fit together perfectly but somehow someone forgot to add some soul and some heart.

As far as story and plot go, Greed makes do with as little as possible on which to hang its gaming framework so don't expect any Machiavellian plot twists or just plain good old storytelling. Graphics and audio design are serviceable although the voice acting is atrocious and the script generally very poorly written. It plays and sounds very much like Sci-Fi B movie.

If you have played any action RPG since Diablo you'll know exactly what to expect. Click and then click some more and then stock up on what ever loot pops out of your enemies carcass. Clockstone obviously don't really understand the fundamentals of the hack and slash RPG - namely gear and inventory. Here you get an inventory that can hold only a few items and items are indistinguishable from the others when viewing them but different by name only  so this ensures that your character will look exactly the same as he or she looked right at the beginning of the game.

The game also struggles to forge an inlay into the cannon that is the science-fiction themed action RPG, of which to be honest there isn't one standout game (Space Siege anyone?). But that does not mean its a terrible game, only a very mediocre one. There is still some fun to be had here, if you can get past the lack of good storytelling, terrible voice work, shoddy inventory system and some boss battles that will try even the hardcore gamers patience.

reviewText:
So imagine Champions of Norrath-lite in space and you have Greed: Black Border. End review.

... INVENTORY TETRIS! :D

...


No, seriously though, Greed: Black Border is fairly good, in spite of some of the horrid reviews it has received. It's an isometric sci-fi action game with RPG-lite elements.

You get to choose one of three characters to respond to a distress call from a mining ship. Each has a different set of abilities, passives and combat style.

The presentation is pretty good. The graphics are definitely more than adequate for the game, with decent character modeling and particle effects for weapons and abilities. I REALLY like the interface. The general gameplay interface, the character, skills, logbook and shop interfaces are all well thought out, clean and easily accessible.

I played the long range character, and the actives and passives on offer seem to provide quite a few different playstyle options. So far I have opted for mostly relying on my range, though it seems as if she could be played in significantly closer quarters for those more brave. I can only imagine the capabilities of the other two. However the equipment options are rather paltry, with only head, chest and weapon slots available, though each slot has a selection of mods that can be socketed into them to add stats or boost your abilities/passives.

There is a decent variety of enemies. Just on the first map, I encountered several varieties of machine and humanoid enemies, all of which were well designed. Speaking of the map, the maps are HUGE. It took me three hours just to clear the first mission. THREE! And the final boss was just madness.

The audio. Oh god the audio. The game's music is awful. The music is really arcadey, and it's on a short loop that it gets annoying very quickly. I shut it off and played my own after about 15 minutes. The voice acting I have seen so far is passable, though, but nothing to write home about.

Only real complaints about the game are no gamepad support, and somewhat obtuse controls. With some time learning you get used to them, but it takes a significant amount of time to do so.

Overall, Greed: Black Border is a decent ARPG for the asking price. There are better out there, but there are also FAR worse. Definitely worth picking up on sale.

reviewText:
Greed: Black Border (GBB) is a mix of Diablo style click to move player character, Kingdoms of Amalur dungeon traps, and top-down shooter combat. The mix is both interesting and frustrating.

GRAPHICS
The game is not processor heavy. Only 12-15% is required from an Intel i7-4770k CPU and 31-41% from an NVidia 770 running at 536 MHz. Backgrounds aren't as pretty, and aside from the frequent explosive canisters from earlier levels, there aren't much to interact from the environment, nor it is purposeful.

SOUND
Most of the interactions (walking on different surfaces, downed enemy, broken tables, plants shot at) are paired with sound effects. The soundtrack isn't interesting, and I got tired from hearing the same (or similar) electronic music by the middle of the game.

GAMEPLAY
The story is short. Enemies, gear, and environments don't have much variety. Add all that and you have what I feel like a grinding game. Controls are also an issue, specially considering how hard it is navigating traps via point and click controls. The control scheme is just inappropriate for this type of gameplay. Rogue style controls will feel better for the mazes and overall gameplay. And, too bad, rogue style control is  not an option in GBB.

OVERALL
I did finish the game without complaining much. I did find it weird that the player can only have one passive offensive perk and one passive defensive perk active at a time. For $0.70, it's ok. Buy it. But increase the price and you'll have better games to play than Greed: Black Border.

reviewText:
Greed: Black Border is too imbalanced in terms of difficulty to recommend.

While the game is beautiful to look at, runs at a great speed despite very intricate pre-rendered and live graphics (the mix of which often causes other ARPGs to get choppy), it's gameplay wildly fluctuates between appreciably challenging and downright diabolically cheap.

It's a shame because at the points in the game the devs get it right, this makes a great play of being a science fiction alternative to other point and click hack and slashers, and makes a very good transition from their predominantly sword based gameplay into gun based action. Effectively, when Greed is good, it is very very good.

This only serves to make the multiple difficulty spikes (actually never mind spikes, cliffs), poorly thought out mobs and insanely cheap sudden deaths all the more frustrating and hard to forgive. The boss fights are next to impossible, and many of the higher level enemies can almost instantly kill you from off screen. Enemies at times seem to shoot you with their highest damage attack from the end of a corridor across an entire map, and in general, the game really forces you to save every time you kill something or suffer the consequences and that really destroys your immersion. To cap this off, there is no enemy respawn or randomised encounter system to enable you to grind until you're too powerful to get cheap-shotted into oblivion during a boss fight or violated into a reload for the cardinal sin of opening the wrong flipping door.

I could forgive the game suddenly going off the deep end without warning over and over if I could've run around doing the equivalent of stabbing rats until I was big and hard enough to not have to worry a la any JRPG you care to mention, but EXP is finite and levelling is painfully slow even on Easy.

I don't mind hard games at all. I have two Ninja Gaiden games and around 50 bullet hells sitting in my games collection, and I've even finished a few of them. I enjoy a well put together challenge. However I cannot stand a schizophrenic, jumpstarting, spiking and above all else, cheap attempt at a challenge. Greed has no balance to it's gameplay at all, veering constantly between laughably easy and nihilistically, keyboard-punchingly difficult with next to no warning, and no amount of high performance, great music (sadly actually FANTASTIC music) or interesting ideas can save it from that one issue.

If you're a hardcore masochist, or you pee EXP and poop cure potions, this might be for you.

But for anyone who doesn't view 200 restarts on the same boss fight because it's got an instant kill homing bullet on STAGE ONE as their idea of fun, avoid.

reviewText:
Greed: Black Border starts you off as a marine of your choice responding to a distress signal. You have a choice between three play styles right off the bat. Short range, Medium range, and Long range. My review is for the Long range character. The basics of my class were just a sniper plasma weapon with some interesting skills and passive skills. Unfortunately, the game isn't really long enough to unlock most of the skills but the ones you do unlock are fun nonetheless.

The graphics are amazing. I wouldn't say that they are very high tier but they have a nice sharp texture to them and they just look great. I haven't experienced any bugs or graphical glitches throughout my full 14 hour playthrough. I understand that steam says that I played for less time but my internet went out and I played offline. Not that any of that matters. The graphical engine is similar to Alien Swarm with less gloss.

I will be the first to admit that there is little to no story in this game. So if you are looking for a wonderful and immersive story, this won't be your cup of tea. This game is more focused on the combat. Let me explain how the combat works. You move similarly to Diablo III with the whole point and click. WSAD are very much useless unless you plan to dodge roll. You can also dodge roll by pressing spacebar and you'll move in the direction your mouse is facing. The dodge roll has a cooldown, about 2.5 seconds at default if I remember correctly. In this game, for long range at least--your shield is your best friend. I added a perk that allowed me to defer some of the damage done to my shield to my energy.

You also have an energy bar which is directly tied to your skill use. For example, a ball that sucks enemies towards it and does massive damage. Something like that may cost 170 energy. In order to prevent skill spamming, this game also has a cooldown for the skill. It's not that long of a wait and it is very effective. I'm not sure if it was a common game mechanic or due to my choice in the passive skill to reduce shield damage by transferring some of it to shield--but when enemies hit me it would reset the cooldown and I'd be waiting twice as long. Not much of a problem for me being a long range character, although this may have an effect on the close range character. I haven't tested it yet.

There is a merchant in this game as there is in almost any kind of game nowadays. The merchant will sell you goods such as, in my case, different damage plasma rifles, armor, health and energy potions. They aren't really a potion but that's what it can be interpreted as. The game does lack in story as well as lootable items. The currency in game is Ikarium, a rare mineral in which enemies will drop, you'll find in lootable sources, and selling items to the merchant. As you are on the last section of the first chapter, you will discover the merchant. He will give you an item which will allow you to teleport to him and sell items. There is a 5 minute RT cooldown in which the merchant will be switching up the items he's selling. If he doesn't have the item you want then, just wait the cooldown out and check again.

A few weapons and armor will have socketed items similarly to the embedded gem system in Kingdoms of Amalur: Reckoning. I was disappointed to realize that once an item has been placed in the socketable items, they are forever embedded there. This is a silly design but it does not affect the gameplay too much. The merchant will typically sell you a small variety of the upgradable items.

The first boss that you encounter has a large pool of HP and you might find this to be very annoying. There are no checkpoints during the boss battles but they have relatively easy attacks to dodge. Just hang in there! Bosses are nowhere near as tankish th rest of the game.

There are three chapters in the game. My first chapter lasted me about five hours, second being around two, and the third being around seven. Overall not too bad. There is definitely replayability as there is new game+.

The point and click is doomed to have some issues with movement as you are not fully in control all the time with these kind of games. Although you can just hold down the mouse button to move and use your mouse to direction, it can still be annoying. Your hands will get tired while playing this game as there is a lot of clicking. The attacking will require you to left click enemies and your skill move will require you to right click. You can hold shift and click in order to attack without the risk of moving towards the enemie accidentally. It does get annoying when sometime you're attacking an enemy and you wish to retreat as they get closer to you, but the game continues to attack and you'll take a hit. This hasn't been a major deal to me as no enemies have landed a killing blow on me due this.

It's a low budget, sci-fi themed Diablo clone.

It's not bad.  It's better for newcomers to the genre than for those experienced with Diablo, Torchlight, Titan's Quest etc.  It has a fairly simple equipment, experience and skill system that won't feel overwhelming.  You can't make too many big mistakes building a character if you just plan ahead a little.  The sci-fi setting is a nice and unusual touch, though the plot is bare-bones.

Some people have complained that the game is buggy but I haven't noticed any major problems.

It supports multiplayer and it might make for a better experience than single player.  Total time to complete the campaign on Normal difficulty is a little over 10 hours.
